TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive Ustic Haplocryepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Upson stony sandy loam, forested.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--1 inch to 0; undecomposed needles, bark, and twigs.  (1 to 3 inches thick)
A1--0 to 18 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) stony sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak coarse granular structure; soft, very friable; 5 to 10 percent stones on surface, 10 percent fine gravel slightly acid; clear wavy boundary.  (10 to 20 inches thick)
AC--18 to 33 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable; 10 percent fine gravel; slightly acid; gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 16 inches thick)
C1--33 to 36 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) loamy coarse sand, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist, massive; slightly hard, very friable; 10 percent fine gravel; slightly acid; gradual wavy boundary.  (3 to 5 inches thick)
C2r--36 to 60 inches; highly weathered granite.  (Several feet thick)

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Grand County, Colorado; 10 miles southeast of Granby; 2,640 feet west, 50 feet south of the northeast corner of Sec. 34, T. 1 N., R. 76 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Depth to the paralithic contact ranges from 20 to 40 inches.  Stones ranging in size from 10 inches to larger than 25 inches cover 2 to 25 percent of the surface.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 25 percent by volume in a major part of the control section.  These range from 1/4 to 1 inch in diameter. The control section is typically sandy loam, but clay ranges from 10 to 18 percent, silt from 5 to 40 percent, and 45 to 85 percent sand, with more than 35 percent being fine or coarser sand.
The A horizon has hue of 2.5Y through 7.5YR, value of 6 through 8 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.
The C horizon has hue of 2.5Y through 7.5YR.  Reaction ranges from medium acid to neutral.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Baldy and Mine series, both of which are deep soils.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Upson soils are on mountain sides and crests.  Slopes range from 3 to 65 percent.  The soils formed in highly weathered granite (gruss).  At the type location, average annual precipitation is 20 inches with peak periods of precipitation occurring during the winter and spring.  Average annual temperature is 40 degrees F., and the mean annual summer temperature is 55 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Scout, Frisco, and Peeler soils.  Scout soils have cambic horizons and are deeper than 40 inches to bedrock.  Frisco and Peeler soils have argillic horizons and are deeper than 40 inches to bedrock.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff: rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used principally for woodland production and recreation.  Native vegetation is ma mainly lodgepole pine, aspen and a sparse understory of grasses and shrubs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  North-central Colorado.  Series is of moderate extent.
